==History==

+
The formal study of ethics began with the early Greeks and later by the Romans. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]] and forms the foundation of what is now referred to as [[virtue ethics]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by the [[stoicism|stoics]] starting with [[Zeno of Citium]].
    −
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. It was in those days that the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] gained a new importance.
+
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the medieval era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. At this time the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] as a source moral authority was of great importance.
    −
Modern Western philosophy began with the work of greats such as [[Thomas Hobbes]], [[David Hume]], and [[Immanuel Kant]] (who gave rise to the [[categorical imperative]]). Their work was followed up by the [[utilitarianism|utilitarians]] [[Jeremy Bentham]], [[William Godwin]] and [[John Stuart Mill]]. [[Arthur Schopenhauer]] is notable because with the publication of ''[[Die beiden Grundprobleme der Ethik]]'', he was the first European philosopher of note to be influenced by the ethical achievements of [[Upanishadic]] writings of ancient [[India]]. The study of analytic ethics went on with [[G. E. Moore]] and [[W. D. Ross]], followed by the emotivists, [[C. L. Stevenson]] and [[A. J. Ayer]]. [[Existentialism]] was mainly developed by [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]. Some modern philosophers who have done serious philosophical writing on ethics include [[John Rawls]], [[Elliot N. Dorff]], [[Jürgen Habermas]], [[Christine Korsgaard]], [[Charles Hartshorne]] and to a lesser extent [[Ayn Rand]].
+
Modern Western philosophy began in the 17th & 18th centuries with the work of [[Thomas Hobbes]], [[David Hume]] and [[Immanuel Kant]] (who gave rise to the [[categorical imperative]]). Kantian ethics is the commonly cited example of [[deontology|deonotological ethics]], one of the major divisions in ethics. In contrast to this and virtue ethics (mentioned above), [[consequentialism]] was developed by people such as the [[utilitarianism|utilitarians]] [[Jeremy Bentham]], [[William Godwin]] and [[John Stuart Mill]].
  +   +
[[Arthur Schopenhauer]] (1788-1860) is also a follower of Kant but is notable because he was the first European philosopher of note to be influenced by Eastern ethical thought, in particular the ethical achievements of [[Upanishadic]] writings of ancient [[India]]. [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] was influenced by both Kant and Schopenhauer but developed ethics into a new direction becoming a powerful critic of the 19th century moral climate, arguing that concepts such as true and false (and good and evil) are merely interpretations of reality. This developed later into [[existentialism|existentialist]] and [[postmodernism|postmodernist]] lines of ethical reasoning.
  +   +
The study of analytic ethics went on the 20th century with [[G. E. Moore]] and [[W. D. Ross]], followed by the emotivists, [[C. L. Stevenson]] and [[A. J. Ayer]]. Some modern philosophers who have done serious philosophical writing on ethics include [[John Rawls]], [[Elliot N. Dorff]], [[Jürgen Habermas]], [[Christine Korsgaard]], [[Charles Hartshorne]] and to a lesser extent [[Ayn Rand]].
